newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigerian stocks stronger despite naira slide.
newsitem.headline: Nigerian stocks stronger despite naira slide.

text.p: Shares appreciated further at the Nigerian stock market on Thursday despite a fall in the naira exchange rate against the dollar, traders said.
The all-share index closed at 8081.82 from 8009.50 on Wednesday.
Traders said the 5.88 percent naira devaluation announced on Wednesday had no effect on shares which continued to strengthen on demand pressure.
"Excess liquidity in the economy has been positive for equities so far this year, but it is now putting pressure on the naira at the weekly foreign exchange market," said one analyst.
The central bank said on Wednesday that 85 naira would now fetch one dollar at its autonomous foreign exchange market.
Bank officials estimated some 111 billion naira was in circulation, putting pressure on interest rates and forcing speculators to buy foreign currency.
Traders said demand pressure sent most equities closing higher on Thursday.
Lever Brothers was among big beneficiaries, up 50 kobo at 23.30 naira, as was Guinness which rose by the maximum five percent or 38 kobo to 7.98 naira.
Similar gains were made in the banking sector. Afribank was 7.25 naira, adding 25 kobo, nearly three percent.
First Bank remained the sector's most prized stock at 16.30 naira, up 40 kobo.
Petroleum marketers finished in their regular strong fashion, buoyed by growing interest in them.
African Petroleum jumped to 57.80 naira with a 38 kobo gain while National OIl at 59.70 naira, Total at 72.50 naira and Unipetrol at 75.00 naira, all rose by 20 kobo each.
Investors continued buying insurance shares in anticipation of capital appreciation and increased shareholding, traders said.
Law, Union and Rock closed six kobo more at 1.70 naira, Niger Insurance finished five kobo up at 4.40 naira, the same as UNIC which ended at 4.95 naira.
Thursday's main loser was packaging firm Avon Crowncaps, down six kobo to 2.85 naira on lack of interest.
